description.narrative: -Improved mobile and broadband access: Access is one of the 3 pillars of IFC''s telecoms strategy, is achieved through overall business efficiency thanks to the co-location model, as the telecoms ecosystem benefits from tower costs spread amongst multiple carriers, leading to improved access (coverage, prices, provision of additional services, etc.). The other pillars i.e. mainstreaming of private and public services and the fostering of innovation, are also achieved by a more efficient telecoms industry. - Reduced capex and lowers operating costs: For telecoms operators, the reduced costs can translate into lower cost of services for users. Potentially, operators can unlock cash from their balance sheets (in the case existing towers are sold to independent third party operators), critical in a region like Central America, where financing options are scarce. - Telecom sector growth Infrastructure sharing is critical in further fuelling the evolution of the telecoms market, indirectly assisting in the development of mobile broadband, and more indirectly, content and applications, mobile finance and mobile advertising, as several industry segments begin converging. -Increased competition: co-location allows smaller operators to have access to a well managed network and they can quickly roll out their network and compete more effectively. - Environmental benefits become evident, especially in reducing the visual burden of the explosion in tower masts (i.e., as a result of mobile telephony markets with as many as 5 operators). - The Project also assists in the creation of both direct and indirect employment opportunities.

Continental Towers Holding Corporation (Continental or the Company) is a Central American telecommunications infrastructure sharing company created in 2008. The Project consists of the construction, operation and maintenance of towers in Central America, as well as the refinancing of its medium term debt. The Sponsor Terra Towers (Terra or the Sponsor), a Guatemalan company, founded Continental and together with a $70 million loan facility from Credit Suisse First Boston, started the Companys operations. Currently, the Company through its operating companies owns and operates about 500 towers in five Central American countries (Guatemala, Honduras, El Salvador, Panama, and Costa Rica). The Company is seeking $120 million of funding to: i) expand its operations by doubling its capacity, bringing its total portfolio of towers to about 1,000 by the end of 2012; and ii) refinance its existing medium term debt facility. The project also contemplates a possible geographical expansion with the penetration of other countries in the region.
